TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed ClientTargetCollection extends System.Configuration.ConfigurationElementCollection
Public NotInheritable Class ClientTargetCollection Inherits ConfigurationElementCollection

Docs.summary: Represents a collection of objects. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> type allows access to the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> elements of the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetSection> section element collection.
It belongs to a group that includes <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> and <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetSection>.
## Examples The following code example shows how to obtain the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> object from the configuration file of an existing Web application.
[!code-csharp[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget/CS/clienttarget.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget/VB/clienttarget.vb#1)]
The following example shows an excerpt from the configuration file.
``` <clientTarget> <add alias= "uplevel" userAgent="Mozilla/5.0 (compatible;MSIE 6.0;Windows NT 5.1)"/> <add alias="downlevel" userAgent="Generic Downlevel"/> </clientTarget> ```

Docs.related: ASP.NET Server Controls and Browser Capabilities

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection.%23ctor%2A> constructor is not intended to be used directly from your code. It is called by the ASP.NET configuration system. You obtain an instance of the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> class by using the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetSection.ClientTargets%2A> property.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Add(class System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget clientTarget) cil managed

Docs.param: The to add to the collection.
Docs.summary: Adds the specified object to the collection.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Before adding a client target to the collection, you must create a <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> object and initialize its <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget.Alias%2A> and <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget.UserAgent%2A> properties.
## Examples The following code example adds a <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> object to the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> collection.
For information about how to get the collection, see to the code example in the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> class overview.
[!code-csharp[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#5](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget/CS/clienttarget.cs#5)] [!code-vb[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#5](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget/VB/clienttarget.vb#5)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Clear() cil managed

Docs.summary: Removes all the objects from the collection.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The result of updating the configuration file after calling the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection.Clear%2A> method is dependent upon the <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode> value chosen. To update the configuration file you use one of these two methods: <xref:System.Configuration.Configuration.Save%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> or <xref:System.Configuration.Configuration.Save%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType>.
> [!NOTE] > Calling <xref:System.Configuration.Configuration.Save%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> is equivalent to calling <xref:System.Configuration.Configuration.Save%2A> when the <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode> value is modified.
If you use the <xref:System.Configuration.Configuration.Save%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method, the following conditions apply:
- If you pass the <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode.Full> or <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode.Modified> parameter value, then a `clear` element is inserted into the `clientTarget` section of the configuration file at the current hierarchy level.
- If you pass the <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode.Minimal> parameter value, a series of `remove` elements are added to the `clientTarget` section of the configuration file at the current hierarchy level. This removes all references to the `add` elements defined in the parent configuration files at higher levels in the hierarchy. With the <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode.Minimal> enumeration value, one additional property on the collection affects what gets serialized to the configuration file. The property is <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationElementCollection.EmitClear%2A> and is `false` by default. One of the following conditions applies:
- When <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationElementCollection.EmitClear%2A> is set to `true`, a `clear` element is inserted into the `clientTarget` section of the configuration file at the current hierarchy level. This removes all references to the `add` elements defined in the parent configuration files at higher levels in the hierarchy.
- When <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationElementCollection.EmitClear%2A> is set to `false`, the `clear` element is removed from the `clientTarget` section of the configuration file at the current hierarchy level, if it exists.
The <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection.Clear%2A> method actually deletes the `add` elements defined in the `clientTarget` section of the configuration file at the current hierarchy level. It also removes all references to the `add` elements defined in the parent configuration files at higher levels in the hierarchy.
> [!NOTE] > The `add` elements are not deleted from the `clientTarget` section of the parent configuration files.
## Examples The following code example removes all the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> objects from the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> collection.
For information about how to get the collection, see the code example in the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> class overview.
[!code-csharp[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#6](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget/CS/clienttarget.cs#6)] [!code-vb[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#6](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_WebNet/System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget/VB/clienttarget.vb#6)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Remove(string name) cil managed

Docs.param: The alias of the to remove.
Docs.summary: Removes the object with the specified alias from the collection.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection.Remove%2A> method deletes the `add` element in the `clientTarget` section at the current hierarchy level and inserts a `remove` element. The `remove` element effectively removes the reference to the `add` element defined in the parent configuration files at higher levels in the hierarchy but does not delete it.
## Examples The following code example removes the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> object from the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> collection.
For information about how to get the collection, see the code example in the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> class overview.
